0.name: Data Structure
0.description: A data organization, management, and storage format chosen for efficient access to data.

1.name: Discrete Structure
1.description: The study of discrete mathematical structures in computer science.

2.name: Algorithms
2.description: A finite sequence of rigorous instructions, used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation, as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

3.name: Computer Systems
3.description: A complex interconnection of the computer's operating system/hardware and its software that work together to provide computing capabilities.

4.name: Performance
4.description: The efficiency and responsiveness of a computer system or application in terms of executing tasks and managing resources, encompassing speed, throughput, latency, and resource utilization.

5.name: Design Patterns
5.description: General, reusable solutions—not finished designs that can be transformed directly into source or machine code—descriptions, or templates of solutions to software problems that can be used in different situations.

6.name: Efficiency
6.description: A property of an algorithm which relates to the amount of computational resources used by the algorithm.

7.name: Software Architecture
7.description: The set of structures needed to reason about a software system and the discipline of creating such structures and systems.

8.name: Cleanliness
8.description: The quality, readability, and maintainability of source code in a software project.

9.name: Optimization
9.description: The process of modifying a software system to make the work use fewer resources, executes more rapidly, or allowing it to operate with less memory storage or draw less power.

10.name: Frameworks & Integrations
10.description: An abstraction providing generic functionality or a standard way to build and deploy applications; reusable software environment that provides particular functionality to facilitate the development of software applications, products and solutions.

11.name: Dynamic Programming
11.description: A mathematical optimization method and an algorithmic paradigm, where complicated problems are simplified by breaking them down into simpler sub-problems in a recursive manner.

12.name: Higher-Order Programming
12.description: A style that uses software components—functions, modules or objects—as values, borrowing concepts from models of computation such as lambda calculus which make heavy use of higher-order functions.

13.name: Maintainable
13.description: Advanced readability, coupling, or consistency contributing to efficient code development; inversely proportional to the amount of time it takes a for a change and to the risk that change will break something.

14.name: Profiling
14.description: A form of dynamic program analysis that measures the space (memory) or time complexity of a program, the usage of particular instructions, or the frequency and duration of function calls.

15.name: Debugging
15.description: The process of finding and resolving bugs (defects or problems that prevent correct operation) within computer programs, software, or systems.

16.name: Responsiveness
16.description: The adaptability of the design in different environments, especially in web development.

17.name: Asynchronous Programming
17.description: A technique that enables the program to start a potentially long-running task and still be able to be responsive to other events while that task runs, rather than having to wait until that task has finished.

18.name: Automation
18.description: A technique to program a script or batch processing that allows repetitive tasks to saves time, reduces effort, and perform complex and tedious operations.

19.name: Modular Programming
19.description: A technique that emphasizes separating the functionality of a program into independent, interchangeable modules, such that each contains everything necessary to execute only one aspect of the desired functionality.

20.name: Version Control
20.description: A class of systems responsible for managing changes to computer programs, documents, large web sites, or other collections of information.

21.name: Monitoring
21.description: The process of observing and collecting data from software applications, systems, or networks to ensure their proper functioning, performance, and security.

22.name: Scalability
22.description: The practice towards a system's ability to increase or decrease in performance and cost in response to changes in application and system processing demands.

23.name: Networking
23.description: Act of using computer code to write programs or processes that can communicate with other programs or processes across a network.

24.name: Cloud Computing
24.description: the on-demand availability of computer system resources, especially data storage (cloud storage) and computing power, without direct active management by the user.

25.name: Parallelization
25.description: A computational task broken down into many similar sub-tasks, processes, or calculations that can be processed independently and simultaneously whose results are combined afterwards upon completion.

26.name: Scripting
26.description: A way of delivering instructions—that automates various step-by-step functions or processes—to a computer (or group of computers), as with all forms of programming.

27.name: Software Testing
27.description: The act of examining the artifacts and the behavior of the software under test by validation and verification.

28.name: Software Analysis
28.description: A requirement analysis that aims to gain insights of behavior, performance, and structure, involving techniques such as examining code, data, and algorithms to ensure the software meets specified requirements

29.name: Data Handling
29.description: Techniques of recording, collecting, and representing data that is presented into valuable insights or actionable information.

30.name: Software Security
30.description: The concept of implementing mechanisms in the construction of security to protect software applications and digital solutions from attackers.

31.name: Software Engineering
31.description: An engineering-based approach to design, develop, test, maintain, and evaluate computer software.

32.name: Distributed Computing
32.description: A system whose components are located on different networked computers, which communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another.

33.name: Usability
33.description: the degree to which a software can be used by specified consumers to achieve quantified objectives with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction in a quantified context of use.

34.name: CI/CD
34.description: The combined practice of frequent merging of several small changes into a main branch, and the rapid and reliable software release.

35.name: Big Data
35.description: Organization, administration and governance of large volumes of both structured and unstructured data.

36.name: Ethical Hacking
36.description: Ethical act of identifying any vulnerabilities or security issues the current system has to improve on its security.

37.name: Computer Graphics
37.description: A sub-field of computer science which studies methods for digitally synthesizing and manipulating visual content.

38.name: Cryptography
38.description: the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of adversarial behavior.

39.name: Research
39.description: The systematic investigation into and study of materials, sources, etc, in order to establish facts and reach new conclusions.

40.name: Artificial Intelligence
40.description: A field of study in computer science that develops and studies intelligent machines.

41.name: Game Design
41.description: The software development of video games by the creation of the mechanics, systems, and rules.

42.name: Computer Vision
42.description: The methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing and understanding digital images, and extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information.

43.name: Data Science
43.description: An interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing, scientific methods, processes, algorithms and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or unstructured data.

44.name: Deep Learning
44.description: The subset of machine learning methods based on artificial neural networks with representation learning.

45.name: Simulation
45.description: The process of modeling a real phenomenon with a set of mathematical formulas.

46.name: VR/AR
46.description: The use of computer modeling and simulation that enables a person to interact with an artificial three-dimensional (3-D) visual or other sensory environment.

47.name: Advanced Topics
47.description: Subjects, themes, or areas of study that are characterized by a higher level of complexity, depth, and specialization.
